entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 5:29AM CST by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary: Areas of fog will be found along the Highway 20 corridor in portions of northeast Iowa and northwest Illinois. The fog may be locally dense at times with visibilities down to a quarter mile or less. If traveling for the morning commute, be prepared for rapid changes in visibility over short distances. When encountering fog, slow down and keep your headlights on low beam.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dubuque; Jo Daviess; Stephenson

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 3 at 5:25AM CST until February 5 at 8:00PM CST by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Kentucky...
Green River at Paradise.
.Recent heavy rainfall has caused rises on the Green River, and the stage at Paradise will crest this evening just above 386.0 feet.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Green River at Paradise.
* WHEN...Until Wednesday evening.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:15 AM Monday CST the stage was 386.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 386.3 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 380.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Muhlenberg, KY

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 3 at 3:22AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in California...
Sacramento River At Tehama Bridge affecting Tehama County.
For the Upper Sacramento River...including Tehama Bridge...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sacramento River at Tehama Bridge.
* WHEN...From early this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 206.7 feet, Water into rv park on east side of river. Tires of trailers get wet. At 209.7 feet, Flood stage - Road inside trailer park and turn around site under RR tracks (Tehama/Vina road) become impassible. Water is into area around structures on east side of river. No structural damage. Sheriff's office issues advisory. Makes sure Pelhams Bay, Snug Harbor, River Inn (small trailer parks all in a row on east side of river north of bridge) know of advisory. At 210.7 feet, Between 210 and 211 feet the county park becomes inaccessible. At 211 feet water begins to enter Driftwood RV fishing resort on east bank of river and just north of the county park.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM PST Monday the stage was 210.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 206.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM PST Monday was 210.1 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 212.1 feet this afternoon. It will then fall tomorrow morning. It will rise to 211.6 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall again but remain above flood stage. - Flood stage is 209.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 212.3 feet on 02/19/2024. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tehama, CA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM EARLY THIS MORNING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 6:09AM EST by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
There are reports of some freezing fog within the region. Some of this is locally dense with visibilities down to around a quarter of a mile.
With temperatures at or below freezing, any untreated surfaces are icy and therefore slippery.
If traveling, use caution, use low beam headlights, slow down, and plan extra time to reach your destination.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 5:02AM CST by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary: Patchy dense fog with visibility of 1/4 mile or less has developed across portions of interior northern Illinois. Expect to encounter sharply reduced visibility and rapidly changing visibility when driving in and out of this patchy dense fog. The foggy conditions should start to improve by the mid morning. Motorists are advised to leave extra travel time, and to reduce speed, use low beams, and increase following distance when driving in dense fog.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Winnebago; Boone; McHenry; Lake; Ogle; De Kalb; Kane; DuPage; Kendall; Northern Cook; Northern Will

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 3 at 5:00AM CST until February 3 at 12:00PM CST by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
...SLIPPERY TRAVEL WITH ONGOING SNOW THIS MORNING...
.Radar depicts an area of heavier snow developing in portions of northwest Wisconsin that will move east through the morning hours. Snowfall rates of 1 inch an hour or greater will be possible at times. Taylor County dispatch reported 2 to 3 inches of snow through 440 AM at Medford and snow covered roads. Motorists should exercise caution when traveling this morning as visibilities may fall as low as half a mile in heavier snow. Snow will lighten and exit the area late this morning.
* WHAT...Snow, heavy at times, for Northcentral Wisconsin. Storm total snow accumulations between 2 and 6 inches are expected with locally higher amounts possible.
* WHERE...Clark and Taylor Counties.
* WHEN...Until noon CST today.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Taylor; Clark

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 5:40AM EST by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
Milder air moving across the snow is leading to patchy fog this morning. The fog is worst on the hill tops. The visibility may drop to a quarter of a mile rapidly.
Also, some low-lying locations may still be below freezing, and any roadways that look wet may be icy.
Use extra caution when traveling this morning.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 3 at 1:48AM PST until February 5 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...A portion of Northern California, including the following areas, Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County and Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County.
* WHEN...From this afternoon through late Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. There is the potential for mud and rock slides in the foothills and mountains.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall are expected over the next 36 hours with totals from 1 to 3 inches in the foothills and 4 to 7 inches in the mountains below 3500 feet. Heaviest period of rain will be this evening into Tuesday night. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 4:38AM EST by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary: Areas of fog have developed across the area early this morning, as warmer air interacts with snow on the ground. This will result in poor visibility of less than a half mile at times. There are still some surface temperatures around or just below freezing which could create some slick spots on roads. Those traveling this morning should slow down and be prepared for rapid changes in visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Erie; Genesee; Wyoming; Chautauqua; Cattaraugus; Southern Erie

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 3 at 4:18AM EST by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog has developed across portions of northeast North Carolina this morning with visibilities as low as a quarter mile to a half mile in spots. This fog is expected to gradually improve later this morning.
If driving, slow down, use your low beam headlights, and leave plenty of distance ahead of you.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 3 at 12:44AM PST until February 5 at 4:00AM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Sonoma, Napa, Marin, San Francisco, San Mateo, Contra Costa, Alameda, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, San Benito, and Monterey Counties.
* WHEN...From this afternoon through late Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Initial rain over the past few days has helped to saturate soils and prime portions of the Bay Area for increased flooding potential as our next AR moves inland. The next round of moderate to heavy rain is expected Monday into Tuesday which will bring additional flooding concerns to the Central Coast where the heaviest rainfall is likely within the Santa Cruz Mountains and the Santa Lucia Range. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

...A WINTER STORM HITS SOUTHERN OREGON AND NORTHERN CALIFORNIA...
.An atmospheric river and stationary front will continue to bring impactful winter weather to the region through Monday with the most significant impacts during the day Monday. * WHEN...Until 10 PM PST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will likely impact the Monday morning and evening commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 8:37PM EST by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
Areas of fog reducing visibility to 1 to 3 miles will blanket Northeast SC and Southeast NC, generaly after midnight through mid-daytime morning Monday. At times, motorists may periodically experience pockets of dense fog with visibility quickly reducing to less than 1/2 mile at times.
When encountering the fog, especially when observing rapidly changing visibilities, immediately SLOW down! In addition, use low beam headlights and allow extra braking distance between you and the vehicle ahead.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 2 at 3:52PM PST until February 6 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
Updated forecast reducing expected peak, but flooding still expected.
* WHAT...Major Flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Along Pit River in NW Lassen County including Big Valley, Bieber, and Nubieber.
* WHEN...Until noon PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Major highly impactful flooding from the Pit river and tributaries are expected to impact NW. Lassen County. Inundation and damage to roads, agricultural areas, and low lying homes and structures in Big valley including Bieber and Nubieber. The current forecast peaks at a similar level to the February 2017 flood event.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 339 PM PST, Major flooding is forecasted by the California River Forecast Center. - The Pit River near Canby is forecast to peak above major flood stage late Tuesday into Wednesday. Flood flows from the Pit river will be joined by numerous tributaries below the Canby gage. These tributaries may lead to flooding impacts in advance of the peak flooding from the Pit River. Flood prone structures in Bieber and New Bieber, should prepare now. Check cnrfc.noaa.gov for updated river forecasts. The CNRFC will transition into 24 hour coverage today through Tuesday evening. River forecasts will be updated 4 times per by 9am, 3pm, 9pm, and 3am. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Nubieber, Bieber, Pittville and Ca 299 At Shasta-Lassen Co Line - The Pit River near Canby is forecast to peak above major flood stage late Tuesday into Wednesday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 2 at 12:49PM PST until February 5 at 3:00AM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...INTERMITTENT PERIODS OF HEAVY SNOW THROUGH THE WEEK...
.A prolonged atmospheric river event will continue through much of the week. Snow levels are currently above 3500 feet, but will rapidly drop below 2000 feet Monday through midweek as a cold front crosses the area. Snow levels will first drop along the North Coast and gradually spread south and inland. Overall snowfall will be inconsistent with breaks between distinct snow showers through Tuesday. There is potential for heavier low elevation snow later in the week.
* WHAT...Snow expected for elevations above 2000 feet. Total snow accumulations between 3 and 8 inches on high peaks. Highway pass elevations including much of highway 36 will most likely to see snow late Monday night into Tuesday morning with snowfall of 1 to 4 inches on roadways.
* WHERE...Southern Humboldt Interior and Southern Trinity.
* WHEN...From 4 AM Tuesday to 3 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Chain restrictions may be implemented for high elevations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will stay low through the week with potential for heavier snow Wednesday and Thursday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Humboldt Interior; Southern Trinity

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM TUESDAY TO 3 AM PST WEDNESDAY FOR ELEVATIONS ABOVE 2000 FEET.

For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow expected. Likelihood of major impacts from snow is greater than 80 percent. Total snow accumulations between 8 and 15 inches, with higher amounts along the Bitterroot spine.
* WHERE...Highway 12 Lowell to Lolo Pass, Elk City, Lolo Pass, Highway 93 Sula to Lost Trail Pass, and Dixie.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 11 AM MST /10 AM PST/ Monday. For the Winter Storm Warning, from 11 AM MST /10 AM PST/ Monday to 11 AM MST /10 AM PST/ Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Winter travel conditions. For MAJOR impacts from snow, expect considerable disruptions to normal activities. Dangerous or impossible traveling conditions. Avoid travel in the impacted areas if possible. Widespread closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes, especially over higher passes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There may be a brief decrease in snow intensity Tuesday afternoon and evening before the next push of heavy snow Tuesday night.

For lower elevations, including Salmon, precipitation may change over to freezing rain for a period of time Tuesday, making for icy conditions.
* WHERE...Shoup, Highway 93 Lost Trail Pass to Gibbonsville, Salmon, Highway 28 Tendoy to Lone Pine, Lemhi Pass, Williams Creek Summit, and Bannock Pass.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM MST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...For MINOR impacts from snow, expect a few inconveniences to normal activities. Use caution while driving. For MODERATE impacts from snow, expect disruptions to normal activities. Hazardous traveling conditions. Use extra caution while driving. Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes, especially over higher passes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Lemhi County; Eastern Lemhi County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM MST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 2 at 12:14PM PST until February 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hydrologic flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast California, including the following counties, Lassen, Plumas and Sierra.
* WHEN...Until 400 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Additional rainfall and excessive runoff will result in rapid rises and potential flooding of rivers, creeks and streams, as well as poor drainage and urban areas, most notably in western Lassen and Eastern Plumas Counties. Minor flooding is anticpated on the Susan River at Susanville, which is expected to crest late Sunday to early Monday. The Middle Fork of the Feather near Portola is expected to slowly rise towards action stage and possibly minor flood stage mid to late this week.
More significant flooding is forecast for the Pit River in NW Lassen County. See the seperate flood warning for additional details on the Pit River.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1209 PM PST, Rainfall over the advisory area is expected to lead to rises along local rivers and streams through Tuesday afternoon. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Eagle Lake, Termo, Herlong, Beckwourth, Doyle, Blairsden, Plumas Eureka State Park, Graeagle, Chilcoot, Bieber, Sierraville, Nubieber, Stampede Reservoir, Verdi, Susanville, Standish, Janesville, Aspen Grove Campground, Antelope Lake and Spaulding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen, CA; Plumas, CA; Sierra, CA

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued February 2 at 11:55AM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has extended a mandatory wood-burning ban for residents in the South Coast Air Basin. The No-Burn rule bans burning wood, pellets, and manufactured fire logs in any indoor or outdoor wood-burning device.
* WHERE...The South Coast Air Basin, which includes Orange County and non-desert portions of Los Angeles, Riverside, and San Bernardino counties. No-Burn Day alerts do not apply to areas above 3,000 feet in elevation, the Coachella Valley, or the High Desert. Homes that rely on wood as a sole source of heat, low-income households and those without natural gas service also are exempt from the requirement.
* WHEN...All of Sunday and Monday.
* IMPACTS...Particles in smoke can get deep into the lungs and cause health problems (including asthma attacks), increases in emergency room visits, and hospitalizations. No-Burn Days are needed to protect public health when fine particle pollution levels are expected to be high anywhere in the South Coast Air Basin. No-Burn Days are based on fine particle pollution levels that are forecasted for an entire 24-hour period, which may not be reflected in real- time air quality maps.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Bernardino and Riverside County Valleys-The Inland Empire; Riverside County Mountains; San Gorgonio Pass Near Banning; Orange County Coastal; Orange County Inland

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT: MANDATORY WOOD-BURNING BAN IN EFFECT

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 5:43AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
AVWREV
The following message is transmitted at the request of the U.S. Forest Service Sierra Avalanche Center.
BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING
IMMEDIATE BROADCAST REQUESTED
05:45 PST Sun Feb 02 2025
The Sierra Avalanche Center in Truckee has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING for the following areas:
NWS Reno NV - NVZ002 (Greater Lake Tahoe)...CAZ072 (Greater Lake Tahoe (CA))
* WHAT...The avalanche danger remains HIGH in the backcountry through early Monday morning. Another period of HIGH danger may occur Monday night into Tuesday.
* WHERE...Central Sierra Nevada Mountains between Yuba Pass (Hwy 49) on the north and Ebbetts Pass (Hwy 4) on the south, including the greater Lake Tahoe area. This does not include ski areas or highways where avalanche mitigation programs exist.
* WHEN...In effect from Sun 05:45 PST to Mon 04:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions exist in the mountains due to intense rain, heavy snow, and strong winds. Widespread avalanche activity is very likely. Avalanches large enough to bury or injure people are expected.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Traveling in, near, or below backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.
Consult https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 6:21AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
AVWPIH
* WHAT...Avalanche warning. The avalanche danger is HIGH. Very dangerous avalanche conditions exist.
* WHERE...The Sawtooth, western Smoky, Smoky, and Soldier Mountains - including the mountains near Atlanta, Stanley, Smiley Creek, Baker Creek, Dollarhide Summit and Fairfield.
* WHEN...From 6 AM MST Sunday until 6 AM MST Monday
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow and strong winds are overloading a very weak snowpack. Natural and human-triggered avalanches large enough to bury people are very likely. Some avalanches will be large enough to snap trees and damage structures.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sawtooth/Stanley Basin

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued February 2 at 6:15AM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
SABSLC
* WHAT...Heavy snowfall and strong winds have caused dangerous avalanche conditions to develop this weekend in the Uinta Mountains.
* WHERE...The Uinta Mountains.
* WHEN...In effect from 6 AM MST this morning through 6 AM MST Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions will develop on many slopes today. People are likely to trigger avalanches by being on or below slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Avalanches could be triggered remotely (from a distance) or from below. For updated avalanche information, go to www.utahavalanchecenter.org. What to do...avoid traveling on or underneath steep north-facing terrain at mid and upper elevations in the backcountry. Carry and know how to use avalanche rescue equipment.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Uinta Mountains

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 6:11AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
AVWPIH
* WHAT...Avalanche warning. The avalanche danger is HIGH
* WHERE...For the mountains of northern Utah and southeast Idaho, including the northern Wasatch Range and the Bear River Range.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow, drifting by strong winds, rising temperatures and rain have created very dangerous avalanche conditions at all elevations in the backcountry. Today, you should stay off of and out from under slopes steeper than 30 degrees because dangerous human-triggered and natural avalanches are likely. People should avoid all travel in avalanche terrain and stay well clear of avalanche runouts.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bear River Range
